poem:
### The Sheep-Pig's Tale  

In fields of whispering ears,  
a runt, pink and pale,  
dreams of voices calling,  
not the slaughterhouse wail.  

From steel gloom to green glens,  
a piglet ponders place,  
finding speech beneath stars,  
in a world blessed with grace.  

Babe, in gentle thought reared,  
speaks where silence grew,  
a tale of hope anew.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Babe review – tale of the talking sheep-pig a charming relic of its time Thirty years ago, a non-Disney talking-animal adventure became a big movie talking point. Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
